column10: b"b' Time Scale Refinements'"

b'b" I\'ve added two functions to the time scale setup: interval and intervalFormat. They allow you to make ticks at particular time intervals (e.g. every month or every hour) and to label those ticks uniformly
column11: instead of defaulting to the highest-order label."'

column10: b'b" Incidentally
column11: they\'re based around the format notations already built in to the time system (
column14: so to get ticks by month you\'d call  "'

column10: b'b" If you want to force a particular time interval for ticks
column11: you should just call the appropriate interval method (e.g.
column12: ) rather than using the scale ticks. I don\'t see that this functionality needs to be added to the scales given that we already have a method for producing ticks for a specific interval. Unless there\'s something I\'m missing? I could see
column14: making it a bit more convenient to map a time scale\'s domain to the arguments to the interval method. Currently you have to compute the extent (domain[0]

column10: b'b" I\'ve added the ability to force a particular time interval for time scale ticks in 1.29.0. For example
column11: you can now say: And you will get 15-second ticks. The way it works under the hood is that the range method now take an optional third argument which specifies the step
column12: so d3(t0
column14: 15) will return the 15-second dates between t0 (inclusive) and t1 (exclusive). Just be sure that you match the appropriate localor UTC-range method with your scale."'

column10: b"b' Chordratio & new chord SVG'"
b'b" I\'ve added the chordratio layout which takes a rectangular array of relationships between entities. Each row represents an entity
column11: each column is that entity\'s contribution to some total value for the column. I also changed the svg chord to a cubic spline in an attempt to reduce path self-intersections."'

column10: b'b" Hmm
column11: I\'m not sure this is a good idea. Wouldn\'t a stacked bar chart be a better way of comparing the entities\' ratios? Grouping things by curved paths is a fairly weak association compared to proximity (gestalt). Also
column12: there\'s a lot of duplicate code here
column13: so I think it would be a lot of work to merge this in. It\'d be better to release this as a standalone plugin."'

column10: b"b' This is a supported variant in Circos
column11: very useful for comparing the output of various clustering algorithms when grouping genomic data (in fact I think this may have been the first application for Circos). I can merge the code back into the chord layout but I was worried about the performance implications of doing so (assuming code duplication is the real worry).'"

column10: b'b" Fix for #1005 fix click suppression after dragend in cases where click doesn\'t fire."'

b'b" Fixes Issue #1005 for both  and  This fixes (which we\'re using at appneta to fix this issue in our app for both zoom and drag) cases when code intended to suppress superfluous click events on dragend causes a later click (anywhere on the page) to be absorbed. Since the undesired click event should fire immediately after dragend
column11: before returning to the JS event loop
column12: the 0ms setTimeout where we clear the handler would only ever fire after the click event.  This should also take place fast enough that most human users would never make a subsequent click before the setTimeout fires. This is a bit hacky as noted in url  but is probably less complicated than trying to discern  where the click does and does not fire."'
